awd_titl_txt: RUI: Determination of the Kinetic Expressions and Mechanisms of the Photochemical Degradation and Oxidation of Dicamba
awd_abstract_narration:
This award by the Environmental Chemical Sciences Program of the Chemistry Division supports work by Professor Amanda Nienow at Gustavus Adolphus College. She is examining chemical reactions of the herbicide dicamba. Although dicamba has been on the market for over thirty years, it is being used more often on agricultural fields now as new genetically-modified soybean plants can tolerate dicamba. The 2017 growing season saw the first use of these soybeans in the US - and by the end of the summer, there were thousands of complaints from farmers on land adjacent to fields. Herbicide drifting through the air appeared to be causing crop damage in down-wind fields. In this project, environmental systems (for example, water or air based systems) are examined to understand how dicamba changes through reactions with other compounds in the environment and through interactions with sunlight. In addition, this project provides research opportunities for undergraduate students, which prepares them to enter the workforce or graduate or professional schools. These students will also help develop and institute a "Chemistry Night" for regional high school students.  The team also collaborates with international partners in France.

The photochemistry and reactivity of the chlorinated herbicide dicamba and the impact of additives in formulated agricultural products is being examined from several angles. These include heterogeneous photochemistry on the surface of epicuticular waxes and leaves, gas-phase photochemistry, and heterogeneous reactivity with hydroxyl radical, the primary gas-phase oxidant. The influence of surfactants and inactive ingredients in the commercial formulation of dicamba on these reactions is examined. The results may provide insight into the photodegradation and oxidation mechanisms and (photo)products of dicamba. This research enhances the current understanding of the environmental chemistry of dicamba. This work also provides new methods to examine the photolysis of chemicals sorbed to surfaces and heterogeneous reactions with gas-phase oxidants. Undergraduates participate in all aspects of this interdisciplinary project and gain experience in a wide range of fields. Prior success with chemistry outreach with young students is expanded upon with programming for regional, mostly rural, high school students.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Agrochemicals are widely used around the world. In 2007, 1,133 million pounds of pesticides were used in agriculture, 531 million pounds was herbicides dedicated to the eradication of weeds. For over 50 years, dicamba, 3,6-Dichloro-2-methoxybenzoic acid, has been one of the agrochemicals used in the United States, historically mostly on corn or grain crops. These early formulations of dicamba have been listed as a restricted use herbicide due to high potential to volatilize, leach from soils, persist in ground water, and to cause widespread contamination of ecosystems. The use of dicamba decreased upon the rise of glyphosate in the early 2000s, but the development of glyphosate resistant weeds means dicamba use is increasing again. In 2016, Monsanto announced Roundup Ready 2 soybeans, genetically modified soybeans branded under the name Xtend, that can tolerate both dicamba and glyphosate. In April 2016, the EPA proposed to allow the use of dicamba in sprays for these soybeans for five years. Despite conditional approval and restrictions on use, growing season 2017 saw the first use of Xtend soybeans in the US - and by the end of the summer, there were thousands of complaints from farmers on farms adjacent to fields where Xtend soybeans were used. Herbicide drifting appeared to be causing crop damage in adjacent fields. Despite the widespread damage (farmers in 21 states have been impacted), on October 13, 2017, the US EPA approved future use of Monsanto, BASF, and Dupont dicmaba containing herbicides “over the top” of soybean and cotton in 2018 and has continued to support the use of dicamba containing herbicides (under some restrictions) in the years since. 

Intellectual Merit

The research funded by the National Science Foundation through project 180827 has investigated the environmental chemistry of dicamba. The two main research questions were: 1) What is the mechanism of the photodegradation of dicamba on epicuticular waxes of plants and on plant surfaces, and how do added adjuvants impact the kinetics and mechanism of the photodegradation of dicamba on epicuticular waxes of plants and on plant surfaces?  and 2) Are photodegradation and/or reaction with gas-phase oxidants changing dicamba on timescales relevant to vapor drift to nearby fields?

A paper addressing the first research question has been published (DOI: 10.1039/d1em00058f). Dicamba degrades by photooxidation, adding on oxygen-containing functional groups over the course of the reaction, thereby making the products more polar (and likely more hydrophilic). The photochemical reactions of dicamba are slower on the epicuticular waxes of corn (zea mays) than in aqueous solutions but follows the same mechanism of reaction. The addition of adjuvants, compounds added to help the herbicide spread on surfaces, led to increases in rate constants in both aqueous solution and on corn wax surfaces. The paper provides several possible reasons for the increase in reaction rate due to the adjuvants; for example, on wax surfaces, the reaction is faster because the herbicide is spread across the surface when adjuvants are used whereas they tend to accumulate in one spot without the adjuvants. 

Examining the photodegradation of dicamba in the gas-phase proved to be challenging – a new reaction system had to be built, new detection methods had to be tested and validated, and methods to deliver the dicamba and gas-phase oxidants to the reaction system had to be created. This work has been completed but is not yet published. With these methods, we were able to run a few photodegradation experiments on gas-phase dicamba. The results suggest that the reaction is slower than we anticipated, with a half-life on the order of days. 

Broader Impact

This project has expanded and improved the available resources to the research group (new equipment, new materials, training opportunities), and advanced a multidisciplinary project that expands the research projects available to undergraduate students. Over the lifetime of this grant, 10 undergraduates worked on the project from experimental design to presenting the results, gaining experiences in skill building, experiential training, mentoring, and communication. All these students, along with over 50 others, benefitted from the “Entering Research” mentoring program the PI developed to discuss career exploration, graduate school expectations, and DEI issues. Five of these students are currently in graduate school or professional careers in chemistry, and five of the students are working on completing their undergraduate degrees. Some of these students are co-authors on a peer-reviewed journal article, and all have presented at local, regional, national and/or international venues. One student traveled with the PI to learn more about photochemical and environmental chemistry research through work with a collaborator in Clermont-Ferrand, France. One student helped develop a “Chemistry Night” outreach event for rural high school students to give the high school students the opportunity to use sophisticated chemical instrumentation to address case studies on forensic chemistry; we will be hosting the fourth annual event this academic year.
